title._content: 44. Aboard the training ship 'Vernon' for homeless boys - The sewing lesson (dated c.1869) John Sharkey

description._content: The Ship Vernon was a destination for vagrant and destitute children, operating between 1867 and 1911. This ship, later replaced by the Sobraon, served as all boy public industrial schools and reformatories whilst moored in Sydney Harbour. Boys under the age of 16 were sent to these schools until they were old enough to enter into an apprenticeship or until 18 years of age. These schools were designed to give them a practical education, as well as an education in religious studies and morals, elementary schooling and nautical training. The photograph features the boys learning the skill of sewing. Sources: blogs.ancestry.com/au/2011/03/03/entrance-books-for-the-v...
